publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l:
────Quid non Mortalia pectora Cogis
Aur\i·over·a Sacra fames.
Fair ones to you who Hearts Command,
And gently Sway, with Fan in Hand,
Your Favourit Punch, a Supplyant falls,
And Humbly for Assistance calls
He Humbly calls, and Begs you'll stop
The Gothick Rage of Vander Hop
Who Invades without pretence or Right
Or any Law, but that of Might.
Our Pigmy Land, and Treats our King's
Like paltry, Idle, Wooden Things
Has beat our Dancers out of Doors,
And called our Chastest Virgins Whores,
Nor has a left our Queen a Rag on,
Has forc'd away our George and Dragon,
Has broke our Wyres, nor was he Civil,
To Doctor Faustus, or the Devil.
E'ne me he Hurry'd with fell Rage
Most Hoarsely Squaling, off the Stage.And faith our fright was very great
To see a Minister of State,
Arm'd with Power, and fury come,
To force us from our Little Home,
Wee feared as I'm sure we'd Reason
An accusation of High Treason
'Till starting up, Cryes Benamere,
“Treason-- my freinds, we need not fear!
“For 'gainst the Brass we Us'd no power,
“nor Strove to save the Chancelour.
“nor did we shew the least affection,
“To Rotchford on Westmeath Eletion.
“Nor did we sing=- “Mac=Hugh he means,
“Thou Villain──I'll Dash out thy Brains.
“'Tis no affair of State that brings
“Me here, nor Business of the Kings.
“···I come to seize you all, as Debtors,
“And bind you fast in Iron Fetters,
“From sight of Every freind in Town
“Till fifty pound, to me's paid Down,
“Fifty Quoth I, “a Devilish Sum,
“But stay 'till the new Haff-pence come,
“Then we shall all be Rich, as Jews,
“From Castle down to Lowest Stews,
“That Summ to you shall then be told
“Tho: now we cannot Furnish Gold,
“Quoth he, Thou lovest Punch to Prate,
“And Could'st for Ever hold Debate,
“But think'st thou that I've nought to do,
“But trifle time away, with You,
“···or do'st thou think, that I am come
“To carry nought but Fatthings home
“Thou Fool I nere do things by Halves,
“Fathings are made for Irish Slaves,
“No Brass for me──it must be Gold,
“Or fifty pound in Silver told,
“That can by any means obtain
“Freedom for thee, and for thy Train,
“Votre trees humble Serviteur,
“I'm not in jest said I. I'm Sure
“But from the Bottom of my Belly
“In sober Sadness 'tis I tell You
“I think it is good Reasoning,
“For us Fictitious men to bring
“Brass Counters made by William Wood
“Which may as well be Understood,
“Intrinsick, as we Flesh and Blood
“Then since we are but mimick men,
“Pray let us pay in Mimick Coyn.
“···Besides 'tis said that you and I,
“Are of the selfe same Family,
“And Faith, I'm apt to think so too,
“For who is liker me, than You,
“For the same Grave and Aukward Grace
“Shews forth it selfe in Either Face,
“And Each of us, with Labour Strutts
“Behind a Ton at least of Gutts.
“We Tally well, in these Respects,
“But best of all, in Intellects.
“For when you made Distinction Learned
“'Twixt the Words, Sorry and Concerned,
“And when upon a Grave Affair,
“Amaz'd you Gap'd behind the Chair,
“They Cry'd───how like to punchenello,
“Is that Same Fat, Clod──Pated Fellow,
“Then Prithy Cosin, let us Buss,
“And cease to treate, thy Kindred thus.
“Quoth he. Thou Vile Mishapen Beast,
“Thou Knave, am I become thy jest,
“Now, not a puppet of you all,
“Shall stir a Step without this Wall,
“Nor Merry Andrew beat his Drum,
“Untill you Pay, the foresaid Summ,
“Then Marching off, with Solemn Pace,
“To write Dispatches for his G--──
“The Revel-Master Left the Room
“And us Condemn'd to Fatall Do
Now fair ones if I e're found Grace
Or if my Iokes did Ever Please,
Use all your Intrest with the Sec
They say he's at the Lady's Beck;
And tho: he thirsts as much for Gold,
As ever Midas did of Old,
Your Charms I'm sure can never fail,
Your Eyes must Influence, must prevail,
Att your Commands, he'll set us free
Let us to you Owe Liberty,
Get us a license now to Play
And as in Duty bound we'll PrayY08B400L
